But Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, became indignant. His indignation was kindled and burned and he became upset with Job because he justified himself rather than God [and even expressed doubts about God"s character].

Elihu"s anger burned against Job"s three friends because they had found no answer [and were unable to determine Job"s error], and yet they had condemned Job and declared him to be in the wrong [and responsible for his own afflictions].
Now Elihu had waited to speak to Job because the others were years older than he.

And when Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouths of these three men, he burned with anger. 'I am young, and you are aged; For that reason I was anxious and dared not tell you what I think. And a multitude of years should teach wisdom. And the breath of the Almighty gives them understanding. Nor may the elders [always] understand justice. I also will give you my opinion [about Job"s situation] and tell you plainly what I think." I listened to your [wise] reasons, While you pondered and searched out what to say. Indeed, not one of you convinced Job [nor could you refute him], Not one of you supplied [satisfactory] answers to his words. "We have found wisdom; God thrusts Job down [justly], not man [for God alone is dealing with him]." Nor will I answer him with arguments like yours. [I speak for truth, not for revenge.] The words have moved away and failed them,' [says Elihu]. But stand still and say no more? I too will express my opinion and share my knowledge. The spirit within me constrains me. Like new wineskins it is about to burst. I will open my lips and answer. Nor flatter any man. My Maker would soon take me away.
Then Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite said,
I thought age should speak,
But there is [a vital force and] a spirit [of intelligence] in man,
Those [who are] abundant in years may not [always] be wise,
Therefore I say, "Listen to me;
'You see, I waited for your words,
I even paid close attention to [what] you [said],
Beware if you say,
Now Job has not directed his words against me [therefore I have no reason to be offended],
'They (Job"s friends) are dismayed and embarrassed, they no longer answer;
'And shall I wait, because they say nothing,
I too will give my share of answers;
For I am full of words;
My belly is like unvented wine;
I must speak so that I may get relief;
I will not [I warn you] be partial to any man [that is, let my respect for you mitigate what I say];
For I do not know how to flatter, [in an appropriate way, and I fear that],

33.verse_text: 'However, Job, please listen to my words, And pay attention to everything I say. My tongue in my mouth is going to speak. And my lips will speak what they know with utter sincerity. Set yourselves before me, take your stand. I too was formed out of the clay. Nor should any pressure from me weigh heavily upon you. And I have heard the sound of your words, saying: I am innocent and there is no guilt in me. He counts me as His enemy. He [suspiciously] watches all my paths," [you say]. For God is greater and far superior to man. That He does not answer [you with] all His doings. And even twice, yet no one notices it [including you, Job]. When deep sleep falls on men While slumbering upon the bed, And seals their instruction, And keep him from pride; And his life from passing over into Sheol (the nether world, the place of the dead). And with unceasing complaint in his bones, And his soul [loathe] even his favorite dishes. And his bones which were not seen now stick out. And his life to those who bring death (the destroyers). One out of a thousand, To explain to a man what is right for him [that is, how to be in right standing with God], "Spare him from going down to the pit [of destruction]; I have found a ransom [a consideration, or reason for redemption, an atonement]!" Let him return to the days of his youthful strength. So that he looks at His face with joy; For God restores to man His righteousness [that is, his right standing with God–with its joys]. "I have sinned and perverted that which was right, And it was not proper for me! And my life shall see the light." ' That he may be enlightened with the light of the living. Keep silent, and I will speak. Speak, for I desire to justify you. Keep silent, and I will teach you wisdom.'
Behold, I have opened my mouth [to begin my speech];
My words will express the uprightness of my heart,
The Spirit of God has made me, And the breath of the Almighty gives me life [which inspires me].
Answer me, if you can;
Behold, I belong to God like you;
Behold, I will not make you afraid or terrified of me [for I am only mortal and not God],
'Surely you have spoken in my hearing,
"I am pure, without transgression;
Behold, God finds pretexts against me;
He puts my feet in the stocks [to hinder and humiliate me];
Look, let me answer you, in this you are not right or just;
'Why do you complain against Him?
For God speaks once,
In a dream, a vision of the night [one may hear God"s voice],
Then He opens the ears of men
That He may turn man aside from his conduct,
He holds back his soul from the pit [of destruction],
'Man is also disciplined with pain on his bed,
So that his life makes him loathe food,
His flesh is so wasted away that it cannot be seen,
Then his soul draws near to the pit [of destruction],
'If there is an angel as a mediator for him,
Then the angel is gracious to him, and says,
Let his flesh be restored and become fresher than in youth;
He will pray to God, and He shall be favorable to him,
He sings out to other men,
God has redeemed my life from going to the pit [of destruction],
[Elihu comments,] 'Behold, God does all these things twice, yes, three times, with a man,
To bring his life back from the pit [of destruction],
Pay attention, Job, listen to me;
If you have anything to say, answer me;
If not [and you have nothing to say], listen to me;

34.verse_text: Elihu continued his discourse and said, And listen to me, you who have [so much] knowledge. As the palate tastes food. Let us know among ourselves what is good. But God has taken away my right; My wound is incurable, though I am without transgression." Who drinks up derision like water, And walks with wicked men? When he takes delight and is pleased with God and obeys Him." Far be it from God that He would do wickedness, And from the Almighty to do wrong. And He will make every man find [appropriate] compensation according to his way. Nor will the Almighty pervert justice. And who has laid on Him the whole world? If He should gather to Himself [that is, withdraw from man] His [life-giving] spirit and His breath, And man would return to dust. Listen to the sound of my words. And will you condemn Him who is just and mighty? Or to princes and nobles, "You are wicked and evil"? Nor does He regard the rich above the poor, For they all are the work of His hands. The people are shaken and pass away, And the powerful are taken away without a [human] hand. And He sees all his steps. Where the evildoers may hide themselves. That he should appear before Him in judgment. And sets others in their place. And He overthrows them in the night, So that they are crushed and destroyed. In a public place, And would not consider or show regard for any of His ways, And He heard the cry of the afflicted. When He hides His face [withdrawing His favor and help], who then can behold Him [and make supplication to Him], Whether it be a nation or a man by himself?– Nor be snares for the people. "I have endured my chastisement; I will not offend anymore; If I have done wrong (injustice, unrighteousness), I will not do it again"? For you must do the choosing, and not I; Therefore say what you [truthfully] know. Indeed, every wise man who hears me [will agree], And his words are without wisdom and insight. Because he answers like wicked men! He claps his hands among us [in open mockery and contempt of God], And he multiplies his words [of accusation] against God." '
'Hear my words, you wise men,
For the ear puts words to the test
Let us choose for ourselves that which is right;
For Job has said, "I am righteous [and innocent],
Although I am right, I am accounted a liar.
What man is like Job,
Who goes in company with those who do evil
For he has said, "It profits a man nothing
'Therefore hear me, you men of understanding.
For God pays a man according to his work,
Surely God will not act wickedly,
Who put God in charge over the earth?
If God should determine to do so,
All flesh would perish together,
'If you now have understanding, hear this;
Shall one who hates justice [and is an enemy of right] govern?
God who says to a king, "You are worthless and vile,"
Who is not partial to princes,
In a moment they die, even at midnight
'For God"s eyes are on the ways of a man,
There is no darkness nor deep shadow
For He sets no appointed time for a man,
He breaks mighty men without inquiry,
Therefore He knows of their works,
He strikes them like the wicked
Because they turned aside from following Him
So that they caused the cry of the poor to come to Him,
When He keeps quiet, who then can condemn?
So that godless men would not rule
'For has anyone said to God,
Teach me what I do not see [in regard to how I have sinned];
Shall God"s retribution [for your sins] be on your terms, because you refuse to accept it?
Men of understanding will tell me,
"Job speaks without knowledge,
Job ought to be tried to the limit
For he adds rebellion [in his unsubmissive, defiant attitude toward God] to his [unacknowledged] sin;

35.verse_text: Elihu continued speaking [to Job] and said, Do you say, "My righteousness is more than God"s"? What profit will I have, more [by being righteous] than if I had sinned?" And your companions with you. And behold the skies which are [much] higher than you. And if your transgressions are multiplied, what have you done to Him? Or what does He receive from your hand? They cry for help because of the [violent] arm of the mighty. Who gives songs [of rejoicing] in the night, And makes us wiser than the birds of the heavens?" Because of the pride of evil men. Nor will the Almighty regard it. Yet your case is before Him, and you must wait for Him! Nor has He acknowledged transgression and arrogance well [and seems unaware of the wrong of which a person is guilty], And multiplies words without knowledge [drawing the worthless conclusion that the righteous have no more advantage than the wicked].'
'Do you think this is according to [your] justice?
For you say, "What advantage have you [by living a righteous life]?
Look to the heavens and see;
If you have sinned, what do you accomplish against Him?
If you are righteous, what do you give God,
Your wickedness affects only a man such as you, And your righteousness affects only a son of man [but it cannot affect God, who is sovereign].
'Because of the multitudes of oppressions the people cry out;
But no one says, "Where is God my Maker,
Who teaches us more than the beasts of the earth
The people cry out, but He does not answer
Surely God will not listen to an empty cry [which lacks trust],
Even though you say that you do not see Him [when missing His righteous judgment on earth],
And now, because He has not [quickly] punished in His anger,

36.verse_text: Elihu continued and said, That there is yet more to say on God"s behalf. And will ascribe righteousness to my Maker. He who is perfect in knowledge is with you. He is mighty in the strength and power of understanding. But gives the afflicted their justice. But with kings upon the throne He has seated them forever, and they are exalted. And held by cords of affliction, And their transgressions, that they have acted arrogantly [with presumption and notions of self-sufficiency]. And commands that they return from evil. They will end their days in prosperity And their years in pleasantness and joy. And they will die [in ignorance] without [true] knowledge. They do not cry [to Him] for help when He binds them [with cords of affliction]. And opens their ears [so that they pay attention to His voice] in times of oppression. Into a broad place where there is no constraint or distress; And that which was set on your table was full of fatness (rich food). Judgment and justice take hold of you . And do not let the greatness and the extent of the ransom turn you aside. Or will all the force of your strength do it? When people vanish from their places. For you have chosen this [the vice of complaining against God] rather than [learning from] affliction. Who is a ruler or a teacher like Him? And who can say [to Him], "You have done wrong"? Of which men have sung. Man looks at it from a distance. The number of His years is unsearchable. They distill rain from the mist, They drop abundantly upon mankind.' Or the thundering of His pavilion? And He covers the depths of the sea. He gives food in abundance. And commands it to strike the mark. The cattle also are told of His coming storm.
'Bear with me a little longer, and I will show you,
I will bring my knowledge from afar,
For truly my words are not false;
Behold, God is mighty, and yet does not despise anyone [nor regard any as trivial];
He does not prolong the life of the wicked,
He does not withdraw His eyes from the righteous [those in right standing with Him];
And if they are bound in bonds [of adversity],
Then He declares to them [the true character of] their deeds
He opens their ears to instruction and discipline,
If they hear and serve Him,
But if they do not hear and obey, they will die by the sword [of God"s destructive judgments]
But the godless in heart store up anger [at the divine discipline];
They die in youth, And their life ends among the cult prostitutes.
He rescues the afflicted in their affliction,
Then indeed, He enticed you from the mouth of distress and confinement,
'But you [Job] were full of judgment on the wicked,
Do not let wrath entice you into scoffing;
Will your wealth [be sufficient to] keep you from [the confinement of] distress,
Do not long for the night,
Take heed and be careful, do not turn to wickedness,
Behold, God is exalted in His power;
Who has appointed God His way,
'Remember that you should magnify God"s work,
All men have seen God"s work;
Behold, God is exalted, and we do not know Him;
For He draws up the drops of water,
Which the clouds pour down,
'Can anyone understand the spreading of the clouds
Behold, He spreads His lightning around Him [against the dark clouds],
For by these [mighty acts] He judges the peoples;
He covers His hands with the lightning,
His thundering voice declares [awesomely] His presence;

37.verse_text: 'Indeed, at His thundering my heart trembles And leaps out of its place. And the rumbling that goes out of His mouth! And His lightning to the ends of the earth. He thunders with the voice of His majesty, And He does not restrain His lightning [against His adversaries] when His voice is heard. He does great things which we cannot comprehend. And [He speaks] to the showers and to the downpour [of His mighty rains], "Be strong." That all men [whom He has made] may know His work [that is, His sovereign power and their subjection to it]. And remains in its hiding place. And cold from the north wind. And the expanse of the waters is frozen. He disperses the cloud of His lightning. That it may do whatever He commands it On the face of the inhabited earth. Or for [His] mercy and lovingkindness, He causes it to happen. Stand still and consider the wonders of God. And makes the lightning of His [storm] cloud shine? The wonderful works of Him who is perfect in knowledge, When He quiets the earth [in sultry summer] with the [oppressive] south wind? Strong as a molten mirror? We cannot state our case because of darkness [that is, our ignorance in the presence of the unsearchable God]. Or should a man say that he would be swallowed up [and destroyed by God]? When the wind has passed and cleared them. Around God is awesome splendor and majesty [far too glorious for man"s eyes]. He is exalted in power And He will not do violence to [nor disregard] justice and abundant righteousness. He does not regard nor respect any who are wise in heart [in their own understanding and conceit].'
Listen carefully to the thunder of His voice,
He lets it loose under the whole heaven,
After it, His voice roars;
God thunders marvelously with His voice;
For He says to the snow, "Fall on the earth";
God seals (brings to a standstill, stops) [by severe weather] the hand of every man,
Then the beast goes into its lair
Out of its chamber comes the storm,
Ice is made by the breath of God,
He loads the thick cloud with moisture;
Its direction is turned around by His guidance,
Whether [it be] for correction, or for His earth [generally]
'Listen to this, Job;
Do you know how God establishes and commands them,
Do you know about the layers of thick clouds [and how they are balanced and poised in the heavens],
You whose garments are hot,
Can you, with Him, spread out the sky,
Tell us [Job] what words [of man] shall we say to such a Being;
So shall it be told Him that I wish to speak?
'Now people cannot look at the light when it is bright in the skies [without being blinded],
Out of the north comes golden splendor [and people can hardly look on it];
The Almighty–we cannot find Him;
Men therefore fear Him;

38.verse_text: Then the L ord answered Job out of the whirlwind and said, By words without knowledge? And I will ask you, and you instruct Me! Tell Me, if you know and have understanding. Or who stretched the [measuring] line on it? Or who laid its cornerstone, And all the sons of God (angels) shouted for joy? When it burst forth and went out of the womb; And thick darkness its swaddling band, And set bars and doors [defining the shorelines], And here your proud waves shall stop"? And caused the dawn to know its place, And shake the wickedness out of it? And the things [of the earth] stand out like a [multi-colored] garment. And the uplifted arm is broken. Or [have you] walked in the recesses of the deep? Or have you seen the gates of deep darkness? Tell Me, if you know all this. And as for darkness, where is its place, And that you may know the paths to its house? Or have you seen the storehouses of the hail, For the day of battle and war? Or the east wind scattered over the earth? Or a path for the thunderbolt, And on the desert where no man lives, And to make the seeds of grass to sprout? Or who has begotten the drops of dew? And the frost of heaven, who has given it birth? And the surface of the deep is frozen and imprisoned. Or loose the cords of [the constellation] Orion? Or [can you] establish their rule over the earth? So that an abundance of water will cover you? And say to you, "Here we are"? Or given understanding to the mind [of man, or to the heavenly display]? Or pour out the water jars of the heavens, And the clods stick together [because of the heat]? Or satisfy the appetite of the young lions And lie in wait in their lair? When its young cry to God And wander about without food?
'Who is this that darkens counsel [questioning my authority and wisdom]
Now gird up your loins like a man,
Where were you when I laid the foundation of the earth?
Who determined the measurements [of the earth], if you know?
On what were its foundations fastened?
When the morning stars sang together
'Or who enclosed the sea with doors
When I made the clouds its garment
And marked for it My [appointed] boundary
And said, "This far you shall come, but no farther;
' Since your days began, have you ever commanded the morning,
So that light may take hold of the corners of the earth
The earth is changed like clay into which a seal is pressed;
Their light is withheld from the wicked,
'Have you entered and explored the springs of the sea
Have the gates of death been revealed to you,
Have you understood the expanse of the earth?
'Where is the way where light dwells?
That you may take it to its territory
You [must] know, since you were born then, And because you are so extremely old! And guide [the stars of] the Bear with her sons?
Have you entered the storehouses of the snow,
Which I have reserved for the time of trouble,
Where is the way that the light is distributed,
'Who has prepared a channel for the torrents of rain and for the flood,
To bring rain on the uninhabited land,
To satisfy the barren and desolate ground
Has the rain a father?
Out of whose womb has come the ice?
Water becomes like stone [and hides itself],
'Can you bind the chains of [the cluster of stars called] Pleiades,
Can you lead forth a constellation in its season,
Do you know the ordinances of the heavens,
'Can you lift up your voice to the clouds,
Can you send forth lightnings that they may go
Who has put wisdom in the innermost being [of man, or in the layers of clouds]
Who can count the clouds by [earthly] wisdom,
When the dust hardens into a mass
'Can you [Job] hunt the prey for the lion,
When they crouch in their dens
Who provides prey for the raven

39.verse_text: 'Do you know the time when the wild goats of the rock give birth [to their young]? Do you observe the calving of the deer? Or do you know the time when they give birth? They cast out their labor pains. They leave and do not return to them. And who has loosed the bonds of the wild donkey [to survive in the wild], And the salt land as his dwelling place? And does not hear the shouting of the taskmaster. And searches after every green thing. Or remain beside your manger at night? Or will he plow the valleys for you? And leave your labor to him? And gather it from your threshing floor? With the pinion (shackles, fetters) and plumage of love, And warms them in the dust, Or that the wild beast may trample them. Though her labor is in vain because she is unconcerned [for the safety of her brood], And has not given her a share of understanding. [So swift is she that] she laughs at the horse and his rider. Have you clothed his neck with quivering and a shaking mane? The majesty of his snorting [nostrils] is terrible. He goes out to meet the weapons [of armed men]. And [in battle] he does not turn back from the sword. [As do] the flashing spear and the lance [of his rider]. And he does not stand still at the sound of the [war] trumpet. And he smells the battle from far away, And senses the thunder of the captains and the war cry. Stretching his wings toward the south [as winter approaches]? And makes his nest on high [in an inaccessible place]? Upon the point of the rock and the inaccessible stronghold. His eyes see it from far away. And where the slain are, there is he.'
Can you count the months that they carry offspring,
They kneel down, they bring forth their young,
Their young ones become strong, they grow up in the open field;
'Who sent out the wild donkey free [from dependence on man]?
To whom I gave the wilderness as his home
He scorns the tumult of the city,
He explores the mountains as his pasture
Will the wild ox be willing to serve you,
Can you bind the wild ox with a harness [to the plow] in the furrow?
Will you trust him because his strength is great
Will you have faith and depend on him to return your grain
'The [flightless] wings of the ostrich wave joyously;
For she leaves her eggs on the ground
Forgetting that a foot may crush them,
She treats her young cruelly, as if they were not hers;
For God has made her forget wisdom,
Yet when she lifts herself on high,
'Have you given the horse his might?
Have you [Job] made him leap like a locust?
He paws in the valley and rejoices in his strength;
He laughs at fear and is not dismayed;
The quiver rattles against him,
With fierceness and rage he races to devour the ground,
As often as the trumpet sounds he says, "Aha!"
'Is it by your understanding that the hawk soars,
Is it at your command that the eagle mounts up
On the cliff he dwells and remains [securely],
From there he spies out the prey;
His young ones suck up blood;

40.verse_text: Then the L ord said to Job, Let him who disputes with God answer it.' I lay my hand on my mouth. Indeed, twice [I have answered], and I will add nothing further.' And I will ask you, and you instruct Me. Will you condemn Me [your God] that you may [appear to] be righteous and justified? And can you thunder with a voice like His? And array yourself with honor and majesty. And look at everyone who is proud and make him low. And [if you are so able] tread down the wicked where they stand. Shut them up in the hidden place [the house of death]. That your own right hand can save you. He eats grass like an ox. And his power is in the muscles and sinews of his belly. The tendons of his thighs are twisted and knit together [like a rope]. [Only] He who made him can bring near His sword [to master him]. And all the wild animals play there. In the hidden shelter of the reeds in the marsh. The willows of the brook surround him. He is confident, though the Jordan [River] swells and rushes against his mouth. Or pierce his nose with barbs [to trap him]?
'Will the faultfinder contend with the Almighty?
Then Job replied to the L ord and said,
'Behold, I am of little importance and contemptible; what can I reply to You?
I have spoken once, but I will not reply again–
Then the L ord answered Job out of the whirlwind, saying,
'Now gird up your loins (prepare yourself) like a man,
Will you really annul My judgment and set it aside as void?
Have you an arm like God,
'Adorn yourself with eminence and dignity [since you question the Almighty],
Pour out the overflowings of your wrath,
Look at everyone who is proud, and humble him,
[Crush and] hide them in the dust together;
[If you can do all this, Job, proving your divine power] then I [God] will also praise you and acknowledge
'Behold now, Behemoth, which I created as well as you;
See now, his strength is in his loins
He sways his tail like a cedar;
His bones are tubes of bronze; His limbs are like bars of iron.
'He is the first [in magnitude and power] of the works of God;
Surely the mountains bring him food,
He lies down under the lotus plants,
The lotus plants cover him with their shade;
If a river rages and overflows, he does not tremble;
Can anyone capture him when he is on watch,

41.verse_text: ' Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook? Or press down his tongue with a cord? Or pierce his jaw through with a hook? Or will he speak soft words to you [to coax you to treat him kindly]? Will you take him for your servant forever? Or will you bind him [and put him on a leash] for your maidens? Will they divide him up among the merchants? Or his head with fishing spears? Remember the battle [with him]; you will not do such [an ill-advised thing] again! Will not one be overwhelmed even at the sight of him? Who then is he who can stand before Me [or dares to contend with Me, the beast"s creator]? Whatever is under the whole heaven is Mine. [Who can have a claim against Me who made the unmastered beast?] Nor his mighty strength, nor his orderly frame. Who can come to his jaws with a double bridle? Around his [open jaws and] teeth there is terror. Bound together as with a tight seal. That no air can come between them. They stick together and cannot be separated. And his eyes are like the [reddish] eyelids of the dawn. And sparks of fire leap out. As from a boiling pot and [as from] burning rushes. And a flame goes forth from his mouth. And dismay and terror dance before him. Firm on him and immobile [when he moves]. Indeed, as solid as a lower millstone. Because of the crashing they are bewildered. Nor [does] the spear, the dart, or the javelin. Bronze as rotten wood. Slingstones are treated as stubble by him. He laughs at the rushing and the rattling of the javelin. He moves across and spreads out [grooves] like a threshing sledge on the mire (muddy river banks). He makes the sea like a [foaming] pot of ointment. One would think the deep to be gray-haired [with foam]. A creature made without fear.
Can you put a rope [made] of rushes into his nose
Will he make many supplications to you [begging to be spared]?
Will he make a covenant or an arrangement with you?
Will you play with him as with a bird?
Will traders bargain over him?
Can you fill his skin with harpoons,
Lay your hand on him;
Behold, his [assailant"s] hope and expectation [of defeating Leviathan] is false;
No one is so fierce [and foolhardy] that he dares to stir up Leviathan;
Who has first given to Me that I should repay him?
'I will not keep silence concerning his limbs,
Who can penetrate or strip off his outer armor?
Who can open the doors (jaws) of his face?
His strong scales are his pride,
One is so near to another
They are joined one to another;
His sneezes flash forth light,
Out of his mouth go burning torches,
Out of his nostrils smoke goes forth
His breath kindles coals,
In Leviathan"s neck resides strength,
The folds of his flesh are joined together,
His heart is as hard as a stone,
When he raises himself up, the mighty are afraid;
The sword that reaches him cannot avail,
He considers iron as straw,
The arrow cannot make him flee;
Clubs [also] are regarded as stubble;
His underparts are like sharp pieces of broken pottery;
He makes the deep water boil like a pot;
Behind him he makes a shining wake;
Upon earth there is nothing like him–no equal exists,

He looks on everything that is high [without terror]; He is monarch over all the sons of pride. [And now, Job, who are you who does not dare to disturb the beast, yet who dares resist Me, the beast"s creator? Everything under the heavens is Mine; therefore, who can have a claim against God?]'

42.verse_text: Then Job answered the L ord and said, And that no thought or purpose of Yours can be restrained. Therefore [I now see] I have [rashly] uttered that which I did not understand, Things too wonderful for me, which I did not know. I will ask You, and You instruct [and answer] me." But now my [spiritual] eye sees You. And I repent in dust and ashes.'
'I know that You can do all things,
[You said to me] "Who is this that darkens and obscures counsel [by words] without knowledge?"
I had heard of You [only] by the hearing of the ear,
Therefore I retract [my words and hate myself]

It came about that after the L ord had spoken these words to Job, that the L ord said to Eliphaz the Temanite, 'My wrath is kindled against you and against your two friends, for you have not spoken of Me what is right, as My servant Job has.

Now therefore, take for yourselves seven bulls and seven rams, and go to My servant Job, and offer up a burnt offering for yourselves, and My servant Job will pray for you. For I will accept him [and his prayer] so that I may not deal with you according to your folly, because you have not spoken of Me the thing that is right, as My servant Job has.'
So Eliphaz the Temanite and Bildad the Shuhite and Zophar the Naamathite went and did as the L ord told them; and the L ord accepted Job"s prayer.
The L ord restored the fortunes of Job when he prayed for his friends, and the L ord gave Job twice as much as he had before.

Then all his brothers and sisters and all who had known him before came to him, and they ate bread with him in his house; and they consoled him and comforted him over all the [distressing] adversities that the L ord had brought on him. And each one gave him a piece of money, and each a ring of gold.
And the L ord blessed the latter days of Job more than his beginning; for he had 14,000 sheep, 6,000 camels, 1,000 yoke of oxen, and 1,000 female donkeys.
He had seven sons and three daughters.
And he called the name of the first [daughter] Jemimah, and the name of the second Keziah, and the name of the third Keren-happuch.
In all the land there were found no women so fair as the daughters of Job; and their father gave them an inheritance among their brothers.
After this, Job lived 140 years, and saw his sons and his grandsons, four generations.
So Job died, an old man and full of days.
